content: Has anyone considered porting the .NET FHIR library to the .NET Core Platform and/or performed any analysis on how much might need to be re-written to work on that platform?

@Peter Jordan I guess it depends what version youre targeting. https://github.com/ewoutkramer/fhir-net-api/issues/178

Seems to work with DNX versions prior to RC2.
Thanks @Matt Berther. Looks as if the roadblock is waiting for DNX v1.0 and that there isn't too much work to do on the FHIR .NET code base.

@Peter Jordan correct, as Ewout mentions on github we have been closely watching the development of .NET Core. Coincidentally, tomorrow we have organized an internal workshop on this topic. Once .NET Core is stable, the FHIR .NET API library will be updated to support the new target platform.
Cheers, @Michel Rutten. I should have guessed that you guys would be on to it!
Just to add a little more flavour to the topic, the client already supports PCL so can be used with Xamarin, and has been tested on Android and Windows Phone/Windows 8.1 Store apps.
So working with DNX Core should be no problem.
Is there any way I can see what version of FHIR is implemented? Or how can I see what version of FHIR was used to create a resource instance?
I want to validate instances and use a service for that, so I need to tell the service what version to validate against.
The resources themselves won't tell you, but the conformance statement of the service that you are talking to will tell you.

Recommend that if you are only wanting to know the version, that you use the summary=true option as this will GREATLY reduce the size of the returned content (grahame's conformance statment is over 1MB in size, and summary doesn't return the resourcetypes.)
If I know what version the server supports, I still don't know what versions the client impl supports.
So I want to check the client impl conformance with the server conformance.
ok, the dotnet fhir client does have the version of fhir it is compiled in so you can ask for it.
Hl7.Fhir.Model.ModelInfo.Version is a static string containing the fhir version of the library
Ah. Great. I'll check it out.
Hmm. ModelInfo.Version gives me 1.0.2, what does that mean? Is that DSTU2?
Correct, v1.0.2 refers to DSTU2 with 1 technical errata published Oct. 24th, 2015. See here: http://hl7.org/fhir/directory.html

Yup. Exactly!
(so good having so much coverage in all the timezones)
Ok. Thanks. But still I cannot see from an instance what version it complies to, right?
correct.
yes, that is a FHIR thing, not a dotnet thing; you can only determine the version from context, not the instance
@Brian Postlethwaite - did you update the generator for the BaseConformance related changes?

@Grahame Grieve was that in the May build, or has it changed since then?
The changes were done for the May build, but haven't been updated since then.
ok, it's after May. There'll be more changes, but you don't need to worry about that

ok, not long till we hit the QA freeze, so will update it then.
How recent is your dev server?
a week?
I might do a build now and try out the unit tests against it to try and get any build issues clear.
Doesn't matter if it's not 100% Just checking that it will go through
there's a couple of new things that caused me grief in the last few weeks
That last commit should now enable the dotnet build to go through clean.

Also pushed the supporting changes in the MayConnectathon branch templates.
Once Have it building clean, will create a new branch with the next version of the spec.

Quick note that the current Dev work on the spec has been updated into a new branch for the dotnet client leading up to the September Connectathon on STU3
The branch can be found here: https://github.com/ewoutkramer/fhir-net-api/tree/ft-connectathon-sept2016

If you want to build locally and update the models at any point,
1. Get the latest source from the above branch from GitHub
2. Run the Powershell script DownloadFhirBuildProfile.ps1 from the build folder
(This will download all the required profile files and example zips - ~80MB, so takes a while)
3. Open the src\HL7.Fhir.sln
4. Run the t4 templates in the Model\Generated folder inside Visual Studio
(in the HL7.Fhir.Core.Net45, and the other 2 projects also)
5. You can then check the diffs in git to see that only new changes have come in.
6. Build the solution!
We are not going to prepare anything with NuGet until the branch for the connectathon starts and there is a stable platform to go from (and therefore will have some servers at known states)
Note: This branch may not have all the latest fixes from the DSTU2 develop branch, but will be cherry picking these forward.
Also note that this is not a complete update with all changes required, but at least covers the model generation, most unit tests do still pass.
